content.title: Liver Disease Coagulopathy
content.summary: Liver disease causes complex hemostatic abnormalities due to the liver's central role in synthesizing procoagulant factors (I, II, V, VII, IX, X, XI), anticoagulant proteins (protein C, S, antithrombin), and thrombopoietin. The resulting 'rebalanced hemostasis' means patients are at risk for BOTH bleeding AND thrombosis. Standard coagulation tests (PT, PTT) do not predict bleeding risk. Management requires understanding this balance: avoid overcorrection, treat specific deficiencies only for active bleeding or invasive procedures.
key_points: Liver synthesizes procoagulant (II, V, VII, IX, X, XI) AND anticoagulant factors (protein C, S, AT)
Factor V is LOW in liver disease (key distinguisher from vitamin K deficiency)
Rebalanced hemostasis: both bleeding AND thrombosis risk
PT/INR does NOT predict bleeding risk in cirrhosis
Treatment: only for active bleeding or procedures; avoid routine FFP for INR correction
content.statement: Liver disease causes complex coagulopathy affecting all hemostatic pathways with both procoagulant and anticoagulant factor deficiencies, resulting in rebalanced hemostasis where PT/INR does not predict bleeding, and management focuses on treating bleeding rather than laboratory values.

explanation.intuition: The liver is the 'factory' for almost all clotting proteins - both the accelerators (clotting factors) AND the brakes (anticoagulants). When the factory fails, both systems fail together, creating a new 'balance' that looks abnormal on tests but may not cause excessive bleeding.
explanation.key_insight: A high INR in cirrhosis does NOT mean the patient will bleed. Global hemostasis tests (thrombin generation, TEG/ROTEM) often show normal or even hypercoagulable patterns. Patients with cirrhosis can clot in veins (portal vein thrombosis) despite high INR.
explanation.technical_details: The liver produces factors I, II, V, VII, IX, X, XI, XIII and anticoagulants protein C, protein S, and antithrombin. Reduced factor levels are matched by reduced anticoagulant levels, maintaining hemostatic balance. Thrombopoietin (TPO) produced by liver is reduced, contributing to thrombocytopenia. Von Willebrand factor and factor VIII are elevated in cirrhosis (produced by endothelium).

definitions_glossary.rebalanced_hemostasis: Proportionate reduction in pro- and anticoagulant factors maintaining hemostatic balance
definitions_glossary.thrombopoietin: TPO; liver-derived hormone stimulating platelet production; low in cirrhosis
definitions_glossary.portal_hypertension: Elevated portal venous pressure causing splenic congestion and thrombocytopenia
definitions_glossary.hypersplenism: Splenic sequestration of platelets causing thrombocytopenia
definitions_glossary.thromboelastography: TEG; global test of clot formation and breakdown
definitions_glossary.dysfibrinogenemia: Abnormal fibrinogen function seen in liver disease
definitions_glossary.PCC: Prothrombin complex concentrate; preferred over FFP for reversal
definitions_glossary.protein_C: Anticoagulant protein synthesized by liver; reduced in liver disease
definitions_glossary.antithrombin: Major anticoagulant protein; reduced in liver disease
definitions_glossary.factor_V: Clotting factor NOT vitamin K-dependent; low in liver disease, normal in vitamin K deficiency
definitions_glossary.hypofibrinolysis: Reduced fibrinolysis contributing to thrombosis risk in liver disease

procoagulant_defects.vitamin_K_dependent: Factors II, VII, IX, X may be further reduced by cholestasis-induced vitamin K malabsorption

anticoagulant_defects.TFPI: Tissue factor pathway inhibitor may be reduced

elevated_factors.FVIII: Elevated (bound to VWF, cleared by liver)

thrombotic_manifestations.DVT_PE: Occur at similar or higher rates than general population

standard_coagulation_tests.fibrinogen: Low-normal or low; may be dysfunctional
standard_coagulation_tests.limitation: Does NOT predict bleeding risk in liver disease

specific_tests.factor_V_level: Reduced (distinguishes from isolated vitamin K deficiency)

global_hemostasis_tests.TEG_ROTEM: Better assessment of overall hemostatic function
global_hemostasis_tests.interpretation: May show normal clot formation despite abnormal PT

differential_diagnosis: DIC (elevated D-dimer, consumption of factors and platelets)
Primary fibrinolysis (no evidence of thrombin generation)

general_principles.avoid_routine_correction: Do NOT give FFP just for elevated INR
general_principles.treat_bleeding_not_numbers: Only intervene for active bleeding or high-risk procedures

FFP.limitation: Large volume, transient effect, may worsen portal pressure

PCC.caution: May increase thrombosis risk in rebalanced patients

for_procedures.low_risk: Paracentesis, thoracentesis often safe without correction
for_procedures.high_risk: Liver biopsy, surgery may need targeted correction

thrombosis_prevention.VTE_prophylaxis: May be appropriate despite elevated INR

definition.@value: Complex hemostatic disorder in liver disease characterized by reduced synthesis of both procoagulant and anticoagulant factors, resulting in rebalanced hemostasis

scopeNote.@value: PT/INR does not predict bleeding; factor V low (vs vitamin K deficiency)

learning_objectives: Explain the concept of rebalanced hemostasis in liver disease
Differentiate liver disease coagulopathy from vitamin K deficiency using factor V
Recognize that PT/INR does not predict bleeding in cirrhosis
Apply rational blood product use for liver disease bleeding
Identify indications for thromboprophylaxis in cirrhosis
clinical_pearls: Factor V is LOW in liver disease but NORMAL in vitamin K deficiency
High INR does NOT mean the patient will bleed - rebalanced hemostasis
Cirrhosis patients can get portal vein thrombosis despite elevated INR
VWF and factor VIII are ELEVATED in cirrhosis (not reduced)
Avoid routine FFP for elevated INR - only treat active bleeding
common_misconceptions: High INR in cirrhosis means high bleeding risk - rebalanced hemostasis argues otherwise
Liver disease only causes bleeding - thrombosis is also increased
All clotting factors are reduced - VWF and VIII are actually elevated
Always correct INR before procedures - many procedures safe without correction

citations.title: The coagulopathy of chronic liver disease

evidence.confidence_rationale: Well-established concept of rebalanced hemostasis with clinical validation
